title: SB 1159
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to make cost, quality, and equity data available to promote innovative healthcare approaches in California. They intend to use a data atlas to assess healthcare needs, control costs, and improve coverage. The Legislature intends to utilize a cost, quality, and equity data atlas in California to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve coverage, address disparities, and increase transparency. The California Legislature aims to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve coverage, address disparities, increase transparency, promote disease management, wellness, prevention, and encourage efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology. The California Legislature aims to promote disease management, wellness, prevention, and efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology to improve health outcomes and reduce costs. The California Legislature aims to promote disease management, wellness, prevention, and efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology to improve health outcomes and reduce costs. Additionally, measures are being taken to reduce unnecessary, inappropriate, and wasteful health care and educate consumers on health care information through the California Health Care Cost, Quality, and Equity Data Atlas. The California Health and Human Services Agency is tasked with researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas in line with the Civil Code. Identification of key data submitters for the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas includes health care service plans, insurers, suppliers, providers, self-insured employers, and trust administrators for multiemployer self-insured plans. A comparative analysis of potential models used in other states and an assessment of additional information to be included in the cost, quality, and equity data atlas, such as data from health care service plans, insurers, and integrated delivery systems. Pricing information for health care items and services collected from allowed charges for covered health care items to enable meaningful comparisons of provider prices and treatment costs. Information on social determinants of health, such as age, gender, race, ethnicity, limited English proficiency, sexual orientation, gender identity, and ZIP Code, along with clinical data from various healthcare providers, is essential for comprehensive data collection. The curr_chunk discusses clinical data from various healthcare providers that is not part of the core data elements for submission. It also mentions the assessment of governance structures involving stakeholders and experts. The curr_chunk discusses governance structures involving representatives of healthcare stakeholders and experts, along with recommendations for funding the cost, quality, and equity data atlas while respecting confidentiality laws. Recommendations for funding the cost, quality, and equity data atlas while respecting confidentiality laws, assessing potential development partnerships, and consulting with a broad range of healthcare stakeholders and experts. The agency will consult with various healthcare stakeholders and experts, including purchasers, to conduct research and make the results available to the public by March 1, 2017. They may use federal funds for this purpose.
